column19: We are a not for profit community association that lost volunteers (temporarily) due to COVID-19. We were unable to deliver our community newspaper to households in May due to the lack of carriers. A social media push to encourage residents to read our online version of the newspaper was only somewhat successful as the majority of our readers are of the senior demographic. Fortunately we were able to publish and deliver our June newspaper.  Our community restaurants and many small businesses shut down as well. We continued to use social media to encourage residents to support local eateries once take-out  efforts began. Several of our annual community events were cancelled due to COVID-19 because the events involved large groups of people coming together for food, music or education. In speaking with residents during the height of the pandemic, I learned that morale had sunk and people were longing to connect. Our association’s monthly  meetings quickly moved to Zoom so that matters and initiatives could still be carried through. Our community is fortunate in that the majority of residents live well above the poverty line. CERB played a large role for those who were unable to work. The long term care facility that borders on our community was hit hard with COVID-19. The  shocking ripple effects of this were evident among our community members. Many of our residents took part in activities to help support this long term care facility.  To this day The long term care facility within our community has not had any cases of COVID-19.  Residents took part in a huge fundraising campaign that our association conducted via social media. Resident donations were matched up to $10,000. Residents felt compelled to help in a big way at such a difficult time. The COVID-19 pandemic brought out the best in people. Our fundraiser exceeded our financial goal.  Over $22,000 was raised. column104: By empowering women, girls and gender-diverse folks, Toronto can boost its economic development in the COVID-19 recovery process. This means preventing gender-based violence, advancing equity, enforcing equal pay and truly addressing Toronto's unaffordable housing market. There is a ton of untapped talent and power just waiting to be released into our economy. For example, women in Canada who leave a partner to raise children on their own are 5X more likely to be poorer than if they had stayed. If you need more proof of how gender-based violence is drastically affecting Canada's economy and job market, check out Aura Freedom's infographic here: https://aurafreedom.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/AF_RelentlessResilience_Beijing25_Cdn_ParallelRpt_SDGSnapShot.pdf  When millions of Canadians are held back due to systemic issues and gender-based violence, we will never see our economy flourish.

column105: Climate change is impacting poor communities in Toronto the hardest. This is of particular concern for the NW part of the city that was recently hit hard by flooding. Our agency was flooded and we had to cancel services as a result. We are in the midst of repairing our space. The same is true for residents in our community whose homes were damaged, and in the case of basement tenants, entire belongings were destroyed. Major flooding is becoming at minimum an annual problem for our community and new development in the floodplain will make it worse. The Black Creek flood plain should never have been sold for development, and it would help our community a great deal if the City took more leadership on flooding prevention, rather than taking counterproductive actions.  In the short-term the city must have an emergency plan to protect displaced residents from extreme weather events  in the long-term the city needs to take proactive action and start building the flooding prevention infrastructure that has been recommended for the Black Creek Area for over 30 years.
column107: The one thing we can likely all agree that COVID-19 has demonstrated the value of is home. Before this pandemic, the number one reason why residents have had to use our services was the high cost of housing in this City. The housing crisis is still very present in the lives of our clients and the high cost of rent has become even more challenging due to the financial hardship caused by COVID-19. It is absolutely crucial that the City takes bold action when it comes to providing housing in Toronto. While the City has less control over negotiating benefits of private developments (even less control after Bill 108), there is no reason why housing developments on public, city-owned land should be anything but truly affordable and 100% rent controlled. The City needs to urgently look past the private for-profit development sector in the Housing Now sites if we are ever going to come close to solving the housing crisis in this city. Public land should be for public housing - publicly built and publicly owned, anything else will only further contribute to the housing crisis.

column104: Support to local community vendors/businesses to remain open will be important.  But adding stimulus funding to support community based entrepreneurship will also be important. It eliminates the risk and related anxiety of having to travel to obtain goods and services.  These kinds of community-based businesses will also generate local jobs thereby creating more opportunity for salaries and spending. As mentioned in our answer to question #9, allowing for additional spaces to be used for licensed child care until physical distancing constraints are lifted will get more children into child care again.  This also will allow more parents to get back to work and/or school, thereby stimulating the economy.
